direction.raw_text: s as a homeland for freed American negroes.  It's been enslaved by one dictator or another ever since.  They even copied their masters' Southern architecture. A tatty pile of weapons - some from World War II - sits in front of a long negotiating table. YURI, blue beret, observes the CHIEF U.N. ENVOY at the table opposite warlord ANDRE BAPTISTE, leader of the National Revolutionary Front of Liberia (NRFL). Baptiste, 40's, is an imposing figure.  In full uniform despite the heat, he wears a jacket one size too small as if he cannot admit his extra few pounds.  His THIRD WIFE stands next to him, wiping the sweat from his brow like an intermittent windscreen wiper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was my first meeting with the American- educated Andre Roosevelt Baptiste.  While the warning signs were all there, no one had any idea what a monster he would eventually become.  I certainly didn't think he would become my friend. Baptiste has a U.N. document in front of him, awaiting his signature, clearly enjoying his moment in the sun. U.N. ENVOY (referring to the meager pile of weapons) --With all due respect, Mr. Baptiste, you don't seriously expect us to believe that this represents your entire arsenal. Baptiste shrugs. U.N. ENVOY (cont'd) This is making a nonsense of the embargo ratified by all five permanent members of the Security Council.  The escalation in the build up of arms jeopardizes not only order in the region but ultimately world order. Baptiste smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --World order?  You say we jeopardize world order? Baptiste's Third Wife wipes his brow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your idea of world order is when you're giving the orders to the world. The Envoy has no response. Baptiste rises from the table, leaving the unsigned document sitting there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. Baptiste is accompanied by two armed BODYGUARDS.  Yuri's commanding officer, CAPTAIN VIVIAN CARLISLE, motions for one of her detail to follow - Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am only going to the restroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orders. They reach the door marked, "MEN".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what they mean by U.N. Observer? Yuri winces at the remark. INT.  PRESIDENTIAL MANSION RESTROOM.  DAY. BAPTISTE pisses at a urinal.  YURI and the BODYGUARDS hang back a respectful distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't you going to help me hold my cock?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't look like a job for two men. The BODYGUARDS stiffen at the insult.  Baptiste stares Yuri down for a moment, then suddenly bursts into laughter.  The TWO BODYGUARDS also start to laugh - cautiously. Baptiste washes his hands, stares at Yuri in the mirror, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know you are fighting a losing battle, my young friend.  War is nature.  If you take away the guns, we will kill each other with knives.  Take away the knives, we will kill each other with sticks.  Take away the sticks, we will kill each other with your peace treaties. (turning to face Yuri) You cannot stop this bath of blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not "bath of blood".  It's, "blood bath".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.  But I like it my way. Baptiste smiles and exits, leaving the words ringing in Yuri's head. EXT.  U.N. COMPOUND - MONROVIA.  DAY. A pep rally for the mostly male U.N. PEACEKEEPERS.  A stage has been erected in the rundown Embassy grounds.  They chant and stamp their feet impatiently. A U.N. OFFICER, acting as M.C., approaches the microphone. M.C. (battling the microphone's feedback) And now, we have a surprise for you.  The
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (aside to his bodyguards as he enters)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rd West African Peacekeeping Corp is proud to present, all the way from El Salvador, the newly crowned Miss World, Ava Cordova. From behind a jerry-rigged curtain appears the vision that is AVA CORDOVA.  She wears a dress that appears to have been sewn onto her. She is obscenely beautiful in the squalid setting. The peacekeepers roar and whistle their approval.  YURI, near the front of the stage, is hypnotized. Standing closer to Yuri than necessary, despite the crush, is CAPTAIN VIVIAN CARLISLE (attractive in her own right but pales in comparison with the Goddess on stage).  She catches Yuri's reaction. U.N. PEACEKEEPERS (chanting to Ava) Take it off, baby!  Take it off! Ava steps up to the microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baby blue.  My favorite color! A roar of approval from the men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose I could give you the speech about "my hope for world peace" but I have a feeling you don't want to hear that today. U.N. PEACEKEEPER (calling out) My hope is for a piece of your ass! They roar again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if you'll be taking me to bed tonight, darling, but you can take her. Ava unfurls a life-size poster of herself in a swimsuit, flirtatiously holding it up against her body.  She tosses other posters to eager hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're all doing a great job - keep it up.  Enjoy the show! On stage, a generic-looking ROCK GROUP starts to play a cover from the 80's - Tears For Fears' "Shout".  Ava dances enthusiastically, provocatively. Ava appears to make eye-contact with Yuri - blowing a kiss in his direction.  He is paralyzed. LATER BACKSTAGE, YURI and other Peacekeepers observe AVA escorted towards a huge, American car.  An inebriated U.N. PEACEKEEPER tries to get her attention. U.N. PEACEKEEPER Ava!  Ava! As the young man reaches out to her, a slick, handsome BUSINESS MANAGER shoves him aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't touch what you can't afford. The Manager slips into the car beside Ava.  The U.N. Peacekeeper and Yuri watch the car roar away. U.N. PEACEKEEPER (regretting indulging the fantasy) Let's get drunk. EXT.  DOWNTOWN MONROVIA - BAR.  NIGHT. YURI and two other U.N. PEACEKEEPERS get loaded on local beer with local PROSTITUTES - one of the peacekeepers pouring beer down a prostitute's throat. From the shadows across the street, a LIBERIAN MAN observes the group. Yuri's colleagues toss some Liberian dollars at a waiter and stagger drunkenly away from the bar, leaning for support on the PROSTITUTES. YURI remains at the verandah, exchanges a smile with a YOUNG PROSTITUTE, at least two years from legal. He's tempted.  He knocks back his drink.  He approaches the girl - presses a few bills into her hand.  She picks up her purse, makes to leave with him but he motions her to stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the smile. Yuri exits alone.  The Liberian Man, across the street, follows. EXT.  DOWNTOWN MONROVIA - STREET.  NIGHT. YURI walks down a poorly-lit sidestreet.  He feels something in his back - stops abruptly.  His hand reflexively goes to his holster. Empty. He turns.  The young LIBERIAN MAN is holding him up with his own gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck, no, no, no, no--fuck, no.  Money?  You want money? (going through his pockets, he starts pulling out loose bills) Fuck, no.  Don't shoot.  Don't shoot me. Fuck.  U.S. dollars. (referring to the face on a five dollar bill) President Lincoln. The Liberian puts his finger to his lips to hush Yuri. The Liberian appears more interested in the gun than the hold-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glock .45. The Liberian produces a crisp U.S. twenty dollar bill of his own, offers it to Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Yuri stares at the money, bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: President Jackson. He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are driving a hard bargain. He hands Yuri a second twenty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, keep it.  Keep the money.  Keep the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you take me for - a thief? The Liberian stuffs the money in the pocket of the bewildered Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Demand and supply. (referring to the gun) There is more I am thinking where this comes from.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want more Glocks?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the Heckler & Koch G-3 assault rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you think I'll do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will come back and shoot you with the Glock. (checking the magazine, referring to the bullets) By the way, do you have the hollow point cartridges? Yuri stares at the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got any color preference for that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly green. (meeting Yuri's eye) I will find you. The Liberian walks away, still admiring his new weapon.  Yuri stares after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd come to the right place - peacekeepers are armed to the teeth.  And nothing but premium product.  The U.N. mostly buys from Switzerland - where else? INT.  CAPTAIN CARLISLE'S PRIVATE QUARTERS.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON two blue helmets lying beside each other. YURI and CAPTAIN VIVIAN CARLISLE are under the mosquito netting of a bed in her private quarters - trying to get each other out of their respective clothes as fast as possible - mouths and hands everywhere. Even in the heat of the moment, VIVIAN is unable to completely let go of her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we doing here, Yuri?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I mean.  Here, in this country.  Are we doing any good?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would nothing be better? Satisfied with the answer, she completely gives in to the throes of passion - pulls him to her. LATER VIVIAN, satiated, dozes amongst the rumpled sheets, backside exposed. YURI uses the opportunity to take an impression of the key attached to her belt. EXT.  EMBASSY COMPOUND.  NIGHT. A white armored personnel carrier sits unattended. The LIBERIAN MAN and two COLLEAGUES approach the carrier's door.  It opens with their newly-made key. The men start to unload the weapons inside the carrier, spilling a box of ammunition in their haste. The camera drifts off the carrier to reveal YURI, behind the barracks, counting a thick wad of U.S. dollars. Spying a lone BULLET on the ground, Yuri picks it up.  We sense he has made a decision from which there is no return. EXT.  INT.  "THE CRIMEAN" RESTAURANT - BRIGHTON BEACH.  DAY. The BULLET has been turned into a pendant, replacing Yuri's Star of David. YURI, wearing a sharp, new suit, enters the family restaurant.  One table of CUSTOMERS - not exactly a thriving concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The starting salary for a U.N. interpreter back then was $32,000.  I made fifty K on "misplaced" weapons on that one trip alone. I doubt the Secretary General noticed.  The U.N. spends more on lunch. Yuri kisses father and Maitre d', ANATOLY, who is adding more Jewish decoration to the window.  He bear hugs mother, IRINA, nearly causing her to drop the plates she is carrying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My tour as a peacekeeper was the perfect preparation for war. Irina notices the change in her son's appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?  You're not my son.  My son doesn't own such a suit. Yuri flashes his killer smile in response. Out of their sight, he slips a hundred dollar bill into the cash register and breezes into the kitchen. INT.  "THE CRIMEAN" RESTAURANT - KITCHEN.  DAY. VITALY, now chef in the family business, prepares a Russian borscht in a kitchen unlikely to pass a health inspection. YURI tastes the food, pretends to gag, spits it out in the sink. Vitaly affectionately cuffs his older brother - the joke obviously a familiar ritual. Yuri takes his brother to the kitchen's rear door. EXT.  "THE CRIMEAN" RESTAURANT.  DAY. At the back of the restaurant, YURI and VITALY sit on the steps amongst the garbage cans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know who's going to inherit the earth? Vitaly looks at him blankly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arms dealers - because everybody else is too busy killing each other. YURI plonks a glossy arms brochure in front of Vitaly.  He takes in the contents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a hell of a fucking career move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the point.  I've seen how the world's coming apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you want to help with that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't stop it. (warming to his theme) It's a basic human need - we eat, sleep, sleep with each other and what else?  Fight. The oldest human skeletons have spearheads in their rib cages. Vitaly is still skeptical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you know about guns?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know which end I'd rather be on. (adopting a serious tone) Every day there are people shooting at each other.  I think to myself, what guns are they using?  Why not mine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vitaly, I've tasted your borscht, you're no fucking chef.  I can eat here for free and I still don't eat here.  You're doing nothing with your life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe doing nothing's better than doing this. (referring to an image of a gun) Yuri, I've actually fired one of these things. Yuri puts his arm around his brother's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I need you. (coaxing) Brothers in arms. Vitaly smiles, looks sold. EXT.  ISRAEL CENTRAL TEMPLE - BRIGHTON BEACH.  DAY. ANATOLY makes his way to the synagogue.  YURI, hastily adjusting his yarmulke, falls into step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally getting in touch with what's important, my Son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. However, instead of the synagogue, he is fixed on another distinguished Jewish man, ELI KURTZMAN, on a street corner also on his way to temple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't God I was trying to get close to. Anatoly introduces Yuri to Eli, who regards Yuri warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad's contacts at synagogue landed me my first Israeli-made Uzis and an introduction to the biggest of the big guns. CLOSE ON THE UNDERCARRIAGE OF A TWA 747, TAKING OFF FROM JFK. INT.  CONVENTION CENTER - PARIS.  DAY. A platoon of attractive YOUNG WOMEN in camouflage mini-dresses show off the latest sniper rifles and grenade launchers. An ASIAN BUSINESSMAN pitches hardware to YURI.  VITALY is more interested in the girls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (referring to the sea of U.N. berets)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) (referring to the face on a twenty dollar bill)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally telling her what she wants to hear)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: can get you the shoulder-fired SA-7 surface-to-air missiles.  The older Chinese model.  Not so effective against modern military aircraft but deadly if used against a commercial airliner.  I'm giving them away at eight-fifty. Yuri notices that his vendor's attention has wandered to a suave older gentleman, SIMEON ZAHAROFF, surrounded by eager VENDORS of all nationalities.  The Asian man joins the enthusiastic throng.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was the eighties and the Cold War was far from thawed.  Most of the deals were government-to-government.  There were some go- betweens - freelancers - but it was a mostly private club with a lifetime club president. Yuri drags Vitaly away from the sales girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's him.  The guy Eli told me about.  Simeon Zaharoff.  Brokered deals in the Iran/Iraq war - both sides, sold missiles to Argentina in the Falklands.  Hets a fucking legend.  I've got to talk to him. Yuri pushes past Zaharoff's entourage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simeon!  Simeon! A BODYGUARD tries to step between Yuri and Zaharoff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're talking. Zaharoff, irritated, nonetheless humors Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mutual friend, Eli Kurtzman from Brighton Beach Import-Export said to contact you.  I have a business proposal.  Perhaps we can discuss it - over a drink. Simeon looks him up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're in the wrong place my young friend. This is no place for amateurs. Simeon walks away without another word.  Vitaly shrugs.  Yuri fumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yob tvayu mat.  (Subtitled - Motherfucker.) Yuri watches Simeon go, surrounded by flunkies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curious how you always revert to your native tongue in moments of extreme anger... INT.  HOTEL ROOM - PARIS.  NIGHT Camouflage minidress and beret are now discarded on the floor - a contrast to the blue helmet seen earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and ecstacy. YURI and VITALY are getting it on with two SALES GIRLS. We pan from one couple in the living room, Vitaly, to the one in the bedroom, Yuri. We focus on Yuri, in the midst of the act - hears his brother's moans in Ukrainian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boh...Boh.  Oh, Boh! (Subtitle:  God...God. Oh, God!) Yuri smiles at Vitaly's cries.  Something catches Yuri's eye on TV. CLOSE UP OF A TV SCREEN showing images of the aftermath of the suicide bombing at the U.S. barracks in Lebanon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vitaly and I found our niche in under-the- counter gunrunning - regimes suffering under sanctions. EXT.  STREET - BEIRUT, LEBANON.  DAY. A street lined with shelled buildings. Beirut, Lebanon - 1986 Through one of the shell holes, we glimpse YURI and VITALY with a LEBANESE CUSTOMER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The job wasn't so different trom the U.N.  I was just as neutral working for the ununited nations.  An equal opportunity "merchant of death", I supplied every army but the Salvation Army. We track with them, only getting occasional glimpses through the holes as they make their way through the war-torn streets of Lebanon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got our start in Lebanon after the suicide bombing. They enter a building carrying a crude rendering of a Coke sign - "Taste Life."  The model drinking the Coke is Ava Cordova. INT.  BEIRUT WAREHOUSE.  DAY. Inside the warehouse is a ten foot high, unruly pile of junked weapons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When the United States leaves a war zone, they generally don't take their munitions. It costs more to bring it back than buy new stock. YURI and VITALY usher the CUSTOMER over to an industrial scale loaded with assorted weapons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sell by the kilo. The CUSTOMER checks the combined weight of the weapons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're second-hand weapons but they're still okay. Both men pullout calculators and start haggling over the price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For all my language skills, I soon discovered that what talks best is money. As long as you can speak dollars, dinars, drachmas, rubles, rupees, pesos, escudos, lira, krones, kwanzas, trancs, guilders, deutshmarks, yen and pounds-fucking- sterling, you can communicate anywhere in the world. Money is finally exchanged.  Yuri and Vitaly leave the Customer with his munitions pot-pourri. EXT.  BEIRUT WAREHOUSE.  DAY. CLOSE ON a row of military decorations on an army jacket. U.S. Army Officer, COLONEL OLIVER SOUTHERN, in dress uniform, adjusts the ribbons on his chest in the side mirror of a U.S. armored personnel carrier. YURI approaches.  In full view, he hands the Colonel a cut of the money. The Colonel places the money in the same pocket decorated with ribbons. EXT.  STREET - BEIRUT, LEBANON.  DAY. YURI and VITALY walk back along the shelled street, Yuri recounting what's left of the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is bullshit money, Vit - small fucking potatoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do we do, go more legitimate?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  More illegal. Vitaly nods thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I'd give right now for a plate of red cabbage and potatoes. The wall explodes with gunfire. Yuri and Vitaly drop to the ground, money flying. The machine gun fire subsides, a shower of dust, fragments of brick and hundred dollar bills still floating to the ground. Vitaly, first to recover, draws his own handgun, sneaks a look through a shell hole. On the other side of the wall, a firing squad of MILITIAMEN has executed one group of MEN, lying contorted, slumped against the wall.  Their bound hands and feet give the bodies a macabre awkwardness. Yuri is scrabbling in the dust for the cash. The Militiamen prepare to execute another six men.  Men?  We focus on one HANDSOME YOUNG LEBANESE BOY, barely in his teens. Vitaly, gun poised, goes to intervene.  A HAND, stuffed with cash, stops him.  Yuri. The brothers' eyes meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not our fight. Vitaly's eyes well with tears. After one look back to the teenage boy, Vitaly reluctantly complies - running with Yuri, heads down, away from the scene. As they run, the wall explodes again with gunfire. CLOSE ON RONALD REAGAN - a cardboard cut-out planted in a sand dune. YURI and VITALY carry a crate from a taxi onto the desert floor in Somalia.  A group of MUSLIM FREEDOM FIGHTERS eagerly surround the crate - Yuri hands the Leader an Uzi machine gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sold Israeli-made Uzis to Muslims. The Muslim Leader tests it - shooting up the cardboard REAGAN. His fighters applaud, Yuri and Vitaly slightly embarrassed. EXT.  HIMALAYAS.  DAY. A helicopter strains in the thin air to land on the Siachen Glacier in the Himalayas. YURI and VITALY, in thick parkas, emerge from the helicopter into near-blizzard conditions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sold to both Pakistan and India in their fight tor the most inhospitable land on earth. INDIAN TROOPS, unseen at first due to their white camouflage uniforms, descend on the chopper - eager to unload the new guns and ammunition. Yuri gasps for breath in the thin air.  An INDIAN SOLDIER gives Yuri a hit of oxygen as Vitaly supervises the unloading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's it going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're making terrific progress - most casualties from avalanches and frostbite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make sure you thaw out the guns before you fight. Yuri nods, takes another hit of oxygen. EXT.  BORDER TOWN - CONGO.  DAY. The town is deserted.  YURI and VITALY are confused as they prepare to unload an arms consignment from a truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had our set-backs.  It's not called gunrunning for nothing. Up the street, a celebration is taking place - a band, balloons, confetti, dancing. Finally, a Congolese man, JOHN "CANNIBAL" NGAWE, appears at the warehouse. The conversation is in French.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cannibal, what's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cease fire, man.  Cease fire.  It's over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?!  What do you mean it's over?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Truce.  We're friends, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friends?!  You can't be fucking friends. Last week I spoke to you on the phone.  You said you would not rest until every last rebel was dead.  You called them vermin. You said would piss in their mouths, you said you would exterminate them like cockroaches.  Just last week, you said this!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was last week, man. Cannibal starts to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cannibal, don't you fucking walk away from me! Cannibal flashes Yuri a peace sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peace, man!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you, Cannibal!! Yuri looks to Vitaly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we can offload it - the Balkans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least when they say they're going to have a war, they keep their word. EXT.  NORTHERN AFGHANISTAN.  DAY. YURI and VITALY stand at a checkpoint in the rugged mountains.  Guns and ammunition are strapped to donkeys tended by MUJAHIDEEN FIGHTERS.  An AFGHANI OFFICIAL inspects the cargo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I even shipped cargo to Afghanistan when they were still fighting fellow Russians. But I never sold to Osama bin Laden.  Not for any moral grounds.  Back then he was always bouncing checks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you're not thinking of selling these, Mr. Orlov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Personal use.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a hundred thousand bullets here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm kind of trigger happy. Vitaly hands the Official his documentation - clipped to it, a thick wad of bills. The Afghani Official smiles.  He returns to his mud-brick border station beside the confiscated merchandise. Yuri focuses on a swimsuit calendar hanging on the mud wall - Miss May is AVA CORDOVA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And everywhere I went, Ava Cordova kept following me around.  We were as international as each other. EXT.  FREIGHTER SHIP.  DAY. We tilt up from the water to find YURI on the deck of a freighter, ploughing the ballpoint blue seas off the coast of Colombia. North of Barranquilla, Colombia - 1989 YURI (V.O.) Operations like mine provided the only way for certain regimes to conduct a respectable war. VITALY holds onto a railing trying to stave off seasickness, not helped by standing downwind from Yuri's cigarette smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The freighter I was standing on carried 113 tons of weapons and ammunition for delivery to one of the poorest nations in Latin America in direct contravention of half a dozen international arms embargoes. Yuri makes a call on his cell phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To keep authorities in the dark, I often spoke in code.  Rocket launchers were "mothers", the rockets "children".  Assault rifles were "apples".  The AK-47 was "the Angel King".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Angel King will arrive tomorrow...Hallelujah to you too. Yuri hangs up.  His phone rings with an incoming call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?...Slow the fuck down--what do you mean, tipped off?  They know where we are?!  Where are they?! Yuri grabs a pair of binoculars.  On the horizon, a fast-approaching speed boat - INTERPOL AGENTS visible on the racer's deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it. VITALY and the CAPTAIN, also spying the Customs Boat, join Yuri at the railing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do we run?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no-one's going anywhere. (to the Captain) Slow--dead slow.  Buy me time. Yuri swings into action, frantically dials another number on his satellite cell phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get that fucking rag down! The CREWMAN hastily complies.  Yuri's call is answered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Yuri.  I need another handle for this tub...something in our weight class. (to an elderly Latin PAINTER, pointing to the stern) You, over the side! (the painter hesitates) Now! The terrified PAINTER makes for the stern where he's hurriedly winched over. Yuri returns to the phone call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it's got to check out...you got a shorter name!...what?--Kono?  How do you spell that?...K-O-N-O.  That's good! He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kono!  K-O-N-O. The PAINTER, nods nervously from his precarious perch, starts to paint. Yuri sneaks another look through his binoculars.  The Customs Boat is closing fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we flying?...Dutch?  Later. (hanging up, to Vitaly) Vit, get me a Dutch flag! Yuri checks the Customs Boat again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn, they're hauling! He checks the Painter's progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Faster!  Or I send you in! (checking the binoculars again) Faster...and better! The Painter's hand is shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri! Vitaly is frantically rummaging through a trunk containing dozens of national flags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have Dutch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got Belgium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck use is that?! (panicked, gesturing to the stern) He's painting a name registered in the fucking Netherlands! Vitaly winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got France?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn it on its side. Vitaly turns the flag sideways - now a makeshift Dutch flag.  Vitaly nods, impressed. Yuri looks forward.  The Customs Boat has almost reached the bow of the freighter. The flag is hoisted.  The Painter, barely completing the last "O" of "KONO", is hauled back on deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it!  Everybody look innocent--now! The CREW resume their normal duties as the Customs Boat slows to a crawl itself, at close quarters with the freighter. The heavily-armed INTERPOL AGENTS eyeball the rusted vessel. YURI focuses on the senior agent - JACK VALENTINE.  While the other agents wear sunglasses, long hair, tattoo or personalized uniform, Valentine is completely by the book.  His Interpol windbreaker clean and zipped to the neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say every man has his price - but not every man gets it.  Interpol Agent, Jack Valentine, couldn't be bought, at least not with money.  For Jack, glory was the prize. The Customs Boat ominously circles the freighter like a hungry shark. EXT.  INTERPOL BOAT.  DAY. VALENTINE never averts his eyes from the ship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not exactly "The Love Boat". Another AGENT hands him a phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's clean?...It doesn't look clean.  I'm boarding. EXT.  FREIGHTER / INTERPOL BOAT.  DAY. From the railing, YURI watches the Interpol boat draw alongside the freighter.  He surreptitiously makes another phone call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Yuri.  Phone in a sighting of the Kristol south of Aruba. The boat is secured to the ladder that runs down the side of the freighter. VALENTINE checks his sidearm, climbs the ladder. EXT.  DECK - FREIGHTER.  DAY. Yuri spies a life ring emblazoned with the word "KRISTOL".  He flips it around as Valentine and the other agents board. Valentine strides past Yuri to a container, nods to an agent to open it.  The large metal door opens to reveal a large container full of grain - grain spilling onto the deck. Valentine is about to plunge his hand into the grain when a mobile phone rings. A CREWMAN calls to Valentine from the bridge of the Interpol boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, sighting of the Kristol due north. Valentine hesitates, returns to the ladder. As the agents go, they fail to see the pile of grain shift in the container exposing a crate of assault rifles hidden there. EXT.  RAILING - FREIGHTER.  DAY. Yuri and Vitaly watch the Interpol boat leap away. On the FREIGHTER, we focus on the terrified PAINTER standing beside Yuri - a pool of urine appears from the trouser leg. Yuri pretends not to notice, slaps the Painter on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice job. CLOSE ON the word, "KONO".  From the "O", a paint drop runs down the stern. EXT.  BARRANQUILLA HARBOR, COLOMBIA.  DAY. YURI and VITALY supervise the unloading of the freighter from the dockside. They are alerted by the sound of a battle raging somewhere on the outskirts of the docks. A Jeep, full to overflowing with heavily-armed NARCO-GUERRILLAS suddenly appears at the far end of the dock and speeds towards them. A military vehicle full of COLOMBIAN SOLDIERS chases the Guerrillas several hundred yards behind. The Jeep full of Guerrillas screeches to a stop by the freighter. The NARC LEADER grabs a box of unloaded ammunition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, pay before you play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're late. The Leader smashes the box on the concrete - bullets spilling everywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, fuck you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you! Yuri tries to play peacemaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you don't fuck him-- The Narc Leader turns and shoots Yuri in the side. Yuri shudders with the impact.  The enraged Vitaly lunges towards the Leader but Yuri, despite his wound, holds him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Vit.  No. (to the Leader, referring to the bullets) Help yourselves.  Free sample. Vitaly nurses Yuri to the ground. The GUERRILLAS ignore them, frantically re-load just in time, immediately start shooting at the approaching government vehicle. The government vehicle throws a vicious 180, almost toppling over. The Guerillas, now back in business, take off after the government troops. Yuri lies on the dock, genuinely surprised by the sight of his own blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first and most important rule of gunrunning is never get shot with your own merchandise. INT.  WAREHOUSE - BARRANQUILLA, COLOMBIA.  DAY. YURI, now heavily bandaged around the waist, and VITALY keep a watchful eye as the NARC LEADER inspects crates of machine guns and other ammunition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The second rule is always ensure you have a foolproof way to get paid.  Credit card, check, cash.  Preferably in advance, ideally to an off-shore account.  It's why I choose my customers so carefully.  Say what you like about warlords and dictators, they tend to have a highly developed sense of order. They always pay their bills on time. The Narc Leader nods his approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I apologize for earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. WORKERS start loading the crates into a truck.  The Narc Leader hands Yuri the suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all there. Yuri snaps open the suitcase - inside six kilos of cocaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six keys of pure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't hand this to my fucking bank teller at Chase Manhattan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should be thanking me. (waving his cell phone) Have you checked the street price today? With the seizures at the border last week, it's jumped thirty percent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sell guns.  I don't sell drugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Diversify. The Narc Leader walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got standards. The Narc Leader ignores him, climbs in his Jeep and drives off.  The truck, loaded with munitions, also exits. Yuri and Vitaly are left alone in their warehouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now what? Yuri shrugs, slices open one of the packs of cocaine.  He takes a bill from his pocket, rolls it into a tube. He goes to hand Vitaly the tube but his brother has already rolled his own. Vitaly dips his tube into the coke - snorts, keeps snorting - a longer inhale than should be possible for a human being. INT.  HOTEL ROOM - BARRANQUILLA, COLOMBIA.  NIGHT. Six kilo-sized coffee cans.  YURI, still bandaged, is pouring the coffee down the toilet and replacing it with the bags of cocaine, mumbling Ukrainian profanities as he works. The last bag is missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vit. INT.  HOTEL HALLWAY.  NIGHT. In the hotel corridor, YURI discovers the door to the adjacent room wide open. Inside, the room is vacant. INT.  BOLIVIAN BUS.  DAY. YURI, clearly fuming, is standing in a standing-roam-only Bolivian public bus along with an assortment of PEASANTS, MIGRANTS and FARMYARD ANIMALS. On the wall of the bus Yuri notices a cellphone ad featuring AVA CORDOVA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found Vitaly twelve days, two thousand miles and 150 grams later in a Bolivian boarding house. INT.  VITALY'S ROOM - BOARDING HOUSE.  LA PAZ, BOLIVIA.  DAY. The outline of Ukraine drawn with cocaine. VITALY, out of his mind, pupils the size of nickels, humming a Ukrainian folk tune, is putting the finishing touches to the map from his badly depleted bag of cocaine. with him, two BOLIVIAN PROSTITUTES, who appear to have passed out or worse. A pounding on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vitaly!  Open this fucking door! Vitaly, absorbed with the task at hand, appears not to notice.  Yuri breaks in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri! (to the comatose prostitutes) It's my brother, Yuri.  He's my big brother. Yuri stares at the cocaine map.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ukraine. (indicating the direction he is going to snort) I start in Odessa, work my way to the Crimea--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --You'll be fucking dead before you reach Kiev. Yuri opens a window, the cocaine blows off the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fuck! Vitaly freaks out, slams the window so hard it shatters.  (The Hookers still don't rouse.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fucking fuck! Vitaly desperately tries to snort the cocaine out of the shag pile carpet - the straw constantly clogging with carpet fibers. Blood oozes from Vitaly's nostril.  Yuri gazes down at his pathetic brother. EXT.  ST. JOSEPH'S DRUG REHAB CLINIC.  DAY. An exclusive rehab center.  A title appears: Upstate New York - 1989 YURI's car pulls up outside, Vitaly in the passenger seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of the car. Vitaly doesn't budge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promised our parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vitaly, you're going to have a good time. This is a top place.  Two Ford models checked in last week and that cute weather girl's been here since July.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. Yuri relents, pours a gram onto the dashboard.  Vitaly snorts it off the dash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a good brother. Vitaly kisses Yuri. Two ORDERLIES open the car door, escort Vitaly away. Yuri watches his brother in the rearview mirror - shepherded up the path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never understood what separated the recreational drug user from the habitual, the functional addict from the dysfunctional.  But for the grace of God, it could have been me snorting lines as long as the Belt Parkway. INT.  CATHOLIC CHURCH - BRIGHTON BEACH.  DAY. IRINA lights a candle in front of the Virgin Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vitaly never got completely clean despite the prayers of my mother... INT.  SYNAGOGUE - BRIGHTON BEACH.  DAY. ANATOLY prays in front of the menorah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and father.  In fact, my younger brother was the only reason my father ever had to question his new religion. INT.  AIR MAROC JETLINER.  DAY. An EXECUTIVE sits in his Business Class seat.  On the tray table in front of him, calculator and spreadsheets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After Colombia I became a one-man-operation. A sole proprietor as you say on your tax return - that is if you're foolish enough to fill one out. He exchanges a collegial smile with YURI who has similar entrepreneurial paraphernalia in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By then I'd mastered my craft.  Selling arms is not so different to selling vacuum cleaners.  You advertise, pound the pavement, take orders. The businessman's smile dissolves when he catches a glance at the brochure lying next to Yuri's "Day-Runner" - glossy photos of GRENADE LAUNCHERS. A MONTAGE OF SCENES - ILLUSTRATING THE ANATOMY OF AN ARMS DEAL. It takes place in an unidentified country in North Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, a good arms dealer also has to be a political scientist.  I go by a seven-step approach. YURI gets off a plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One: identity a government and an opposition where the opposition is ignored. YURI immediately picks up a newspaper, eager for the latest news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two: Wait for a radical group to break away from the opposition. YURI is buoyed by the front page news, over-tips the NEWSPAPER SELLER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three: Immediately approach the radical group and offer them arms. YURI meets a group of REVOLUTIONARIES in a backstreet bar, shows them an arms catalogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four: Whether they buy or not, inform the government that the radical group approached you and offer the government arms. YURI meets a GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL in the parliament buildings, shows him the same catalogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five: Whether they buy or not, re-approach the radical group and offer them more arms but now at a higher price.  Increasing tension is a means of generating demand and the ideal situation is to sell to both sides. YURI meets the REVOLUTIONARIES a second time in the same bar - this time they are more enthusiastic and Yuri has his calculator out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six: If they start shooting at each other, the escalation is underway. YURI, now accompanied by bodyguards, is escorted into the government buildings, where he's given a fat envelope. Back at the bar, YURI is given an even fatter envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are consuming small arms and ammunition and the cash register is well and truly ringing. YURI stands at his hotel window, sneaking a look through grimy venetian blinds.  A street battle is taking place. However, in Yuri's mind the sound of the gunshots is gradually replaced by the sound ot a cash register.  Each time a gun is fired, the register rings. Yuri shuts the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven: Don't forget that the success of a radical group in one country can inspire a radical group in a neighboring country. Yuri boards a plane, taking off for a new conflict zone. INT.  AIR MAROC JETLINER.  DAY. YURI leans back in his Business Class seat - eyes closed.  They suddenly blink open.  He feels someone watching him. Sure enough, he is face-to-face with AVA CORDOVA - staring at him from a magazine cover in the seat pocket next to him. INT.  MODEL AGENCY.  DAY. A gallery of MODELS from the late-eighties on VOGUE, HARPER'S BAZAAR, ELLE magazine covers, blown-up and framed on a white wall. An AGENT with a window-office overlooking Park Avenue talks on the phone.  In front of her, the headshot of AVA CORDOVA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --There's really no one else you'd consider? Christie and Brooke are both available...not the right look?  It's just that Ava doesn't generally do print. The agent examines an envelope stuffed with cash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: However, since you are willing to double her rate and pay cash in advance.  She loves working with Herb and you say the campaign will only be seen in Asia? (examining a first class plane ticket Destination: St. Barts) I certainly can't see her objecting to the location. (inspecting an itinerary) What is the product again...? INT.  ARMS SHOW CONVENTION HALL.  DAY. YURI talks on a phone as he browses at an arms show.  He stops at a display of handguns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The product?  Er,...Colt .45. (a beat) The beer. INT.  EDEN ROCK HOTEL - ST. BARTHELEMY, FRENCH CARIBBEAN.  DAY. An idyllic beachfront hotel. AVA CORDOVA enters an empty reception area.  The RECEPTIONIST hands her a fax - Ava's face falls. YURI sits by the deserted pool, observing her entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It cost me twenty for the fake booking, another twelve to buy out the hotel.  You can't force someone to tall in love with you but you can sure make ita damn sight easier. INT.  HOTEL RESTAURANT.  DUSK. A large restaurant overlooking the ocean. AVA and YURI are the only guests, both eating alone.  They make eye- contact - exchange polite smiles. EXT.  PRIVATE BEACH.  DAY. AVA strolls down to the beach, deserted, save for YURI - sunbathing some distance away on one of the hundred empty sunbeds. Ava dives into the water.  Behind his sunglasses, Yuri watches her. LATER Towelling off on a sunbed of her own, Ava glances over to Yuri.  It seems crazy not to speak to each other.  Ava breaks the ice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Popular hotel, huh? Yuri smiles.  Ava approaches, extends a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ava Cordova.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri Orlov.  What brings you to St. Barts?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A photo shoot.  At least, that was the plan. But the photographer's plane got stuck in Miami.  Hurricane - though there was nothing in the news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those things can come out of nowhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The job's cancelled and there's no flight back to New York 'til Tuesday. Yuri pretends to ponder her predicament.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can hitch a ride with me if you like. Ava regards him cautiously - likes what she sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the meantime, why don't I take your picture? Ava smiles, poses playfully for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my experience some of the most successful relationships are founded on lies and deceit.  Since that's where they usually end up anyway, it's a logical place to start. EXT.  ST. BARTHELEMY AIRPORT.  DAY. A limousine approaches a Lear jet parked on the tarmac of the one- runway airport.  YURI and AVA exit the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I nearly went broke trying to convince her I was anything but.  I knew Ava was not the kind of woman to be seduced by a ride in a private jet unless you owned the jet. CLOSE ON the tail of the jet - the name "ORLOV AIR".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is your plane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is my name. They enter the plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I was lying.  The plane was a rental, like the car and even the suit I was standing in.  At the last minute, I bribed the crew for the paint-job. As the plane picks up speed on the runway, the name "ORLOV" smears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luckily, by the time we landed, Ava wasn't looking anywhere but in my eyes. INT.  LEAR JET.  DAY. YURI and AVA sit beside each other on a white leather sofa in the customized cabin drinking Cristal champagne. Yuri glances through Vogue magazine - a photo spread on Ava.  Ava takes in the plane's sumptuous appointments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had no idea. He hands her back the magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry I didn't recognize you.  You must think me very rude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't apologize.  I put on clothes for a living.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least you aren't taking them off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would be if half the photographers had their way. (shrug) But I can't complain.  I'm paid to say, "Cheese". (meeting his gaze) What about you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing so glamorous.  I'm in transport - international air freight mostly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, like UPS or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Business is good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like you, I can't complain. They both drink.  A thought occurs to Ava.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But if you did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...I don't know. (reluctant admission) It's just that I travel all around the world but I can't help feeling sometimes that I'm going nowhere. Ava regards him closely.  He's echoed her thoughts.  Yuri pours Ava another drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's to... (raising his glass) ...a hurricane. They toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without it, I'd never have met you. She meets his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is no accident, is it, Yuri? Yuri freezes - doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It feels like fate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe in fate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you believe in? Yuri gazes at her a moment - he answers her question with a kiss. Ava does not pull away. INT.  LEAR JET - BEDROOM.  DAY. CLOUDS rush by the faces of YURI and AVA, heads close to the plane's oval windows. They make love in a wall-to-wall bed built into the rear of the jet. The camera moves past the couple through one of the plane's windows, and the clouds begin to rain. EXT.  ISRAEL CENTRAL TEMPLE - BRIGHTON BEACH.  DAY. Confetti.  YURI and AVA run through the paper shower as they descend the steps of a synagogue in Brighton Beach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We married in a synagogue to make my father happy.  In the eyes of my Catholic mother, it was worse than living in sin. Yuri and Ava kiss his parents, ANATOLY and IRINA. As the happy couple reaches the limousine, VITALY - out of rehab and out of his mind - fires an AK-47 into the air as a salute. The GUESTS drop to the ground - the only ones left standing are Yuri and Vitaly. Yuri stares daggers at Vitaly, helps Ava to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's traditional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Traditional. The guests nod, uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One more time, Vitaly. Vitaly lets go another burst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I should have said something. INT.  UPPER EAST SIDE APARTMENT.  DAY. YURI carries AVA over the threshold of their new home to cheers of the assembled GUESTS. ANATOLY and IRINA gape in amazement at the grand house.  They draw their son aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always remember, son, there's something above you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Dad.  A forty-thousand dollar crystal chandelier. Anatoly forces a smile.  Irina presses a gift into Yuri's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom, we don't need anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need this. Irina takes Anatoly's arm, they walk away. Yuri, alone for a moment, opens the package - a small Roman Catholic Bible, conveniently bookmarked at the Ten Commandments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT.  UPPER EAST SIDE APARTMENT.  DAY. A newborn baby boy, NICOLAI, plays in the wrapping paper of opened gifts beneath an extravagantly-decorated Christmas tree. New York - December 25, 1991 YURI (V.O.) I was still living way beyond my means, mortgaged to the hilt, using one credit card to payoff another.  Anything to keep Ava in the style to which she had, thanks largely to me, become accustomed.  Then suddenly all my Christmases came at once. A family Christmas - Anatoly, Irina and Ava open gifts.  Baby Nicolai wriggles on a blanket, trying to reach a piece of tinsel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus was Jewish.  You're worshipping a Jew. Irina ignores him.  She regards a gift - a silver goblet set from Tiffany's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ava, this is too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri likes to spoil you. Nicolai crawls an inch.  AVA beams proudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nicki!  You did it.  Good boy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my grandson. Ava looks around for Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri.  Don't you want to see what your son is doing? No reply.  Ava wraps the piece of tinsel around the baby's head. A loud shout from the other room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tak!  Tak!  Tak-fucking-tak!  (subtitle: Yes!) Ava scoops up the baby.  With Anatoly and Irina, they go to investigate. On the television, MIKHAIL GORBACHEV, is making his famous speech, officially ending the Cold War. Yuri kneels in front of the TV as if it is an altar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's over!  It's over!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's over?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cold War, the Soviet Union, the Evil Empire.  Mikhail's saying "no mas".  He's throwing in the towel.  It's over. Yuri kisses Ava, Nicolai, Anatoly, Irina, kisses the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's nice. (referring to Nicolai) Your son is crawling. Yuri's too busy kissing Gorbachev's birthmark. He gazes at the TV, revelling in the plan taking shape in his head. LATER In the living room, AVA and IRINA play with NICOLAI.  YURI and ANATOLY drink Johnnie Walker Black label.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least there'll be religious freedom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'll go back for a visit. (trying to sound casual) Do you stay in touch with Uncle Dmitri?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dmitri Volkoff?  Now and then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The luckiest man alive.  You know he was one of the first men at Chernobyl.  Off-duty, at his daughter's wedding, he was roaring drunk.  He was the only one who survived. Later they found that alcohol in your blood resists radiation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's still a General in the army?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Major General.  He got promoted.  Two of his rivals were also there that day.  I told you - he's the luckiest man alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He may be luckier than you think. Yuri goes to pour himself a drink.  Anatoly grabs his son's hand the way he did many years earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not fools, Yuri.  What's between you and your wife is your own business but I don't think you're going to Odessa to open a McDonald's. (meeting his son's eye) Is this how you want to be remembered?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're only remembered when you're dead. Yuri knocks back his vodka, tries to lighten the mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll bring you back some caviar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not kosher. A crash.  VITALY and a call-girl, ANGEL, dressed in a low-cut fairy dress, stumble through the front door - both the worse for drink and drugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merry fucking Christmas! Angel laughs.  The family gazes at Vitaly and his friend, appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vitaly, who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her name really is Angel.  She's a fairy. (hoisting Angel) Let's stick her on top of the Christmas tree. Vitaly and Angel laugh.  No one else does. Vitaly collapses on the floor.  Nicolai cries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you all. Yuri firmly escorts Angel to the door and pays her off. EXT.  ST. JOSEPH'S DRUG REHAB CLINIC - UPSTATE NEW YORK.  DAY. YURI drops VITALY back at the exclusive rehab center. By now Yuri knows the routine.  He pours a gram onto the dashboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going back to Ukraine. Vitaly snorts it off the dash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss Odessa.  I miss you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss you too. Vitaly kisses Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful, Yuri.  Those things you sell, kill... (tapping Yuri's chest where his heart should be) ...inside. Two ORDERLIES open the car door, escort Vitaly away.  Yuri stares after Vitaly. INT.  UPPER EASTSIDE APARTMENT.  DAY. AVA and NICKI kiss YURI goodbye. EXT./INT.  PUBLIC STORAGE FACILITY - MANHATTAN.  MORNING. YURI enters a public storage facility, opens a locker with a combination lock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no problem leading a double life. It's the triple and quadruple lives that get you in the end. He produces several passports from the locker, shuffles the passports like playing cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back then I carried a French, British, Israeli and Ukrainian passport and a student visa for the U.S., but that's another story. The locker also contains five identical briefcases - presumably he can tell them apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I also packed five different briefcases depending on the region of the world I was visiting. EXT.  BORDER CHECKPOINT - IZMAYIL, UKRAINE.  DAY. Light snow falls.  YURI, driving a brand new Mercedes, waits in a long line of cars at the border. Izmayil, Ukraine - January, 1992 YURI (V.O.) The end of the Cold War was the beginning of the hottest time in arms dealing.  The Wall had fallen.  The arms bazaar was open. Those forty-five years had generated the highest weapons build-up in history.  The Soviets had tanks and guns coming out the demon hole - huge stockpiles and now no enemy. A Border Guard approaches Yuri's car window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visa? Yuri hands the Guard his passport.  Inside, a credit card emblazoned, "VISA". The guard smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cash or check only. Yuri smiles, hands him several U.S. bills.  Yuri's passport is promptly stamped.  He is waved past the line of cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's good to be home. EXT.  ODESSA MILITARY BASE.  DAY. YURI, briefcase in hand, meets his Uncle DMITRI at a barracks.  (NB: Dmitri always carries a hip flask of vodka as if there is a constant threat of radiation poisoning.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nephew, come here and hug the luckiest man alive. The General gives him a great bear hug.  Dmitri registers the apprehensive look on Yuri's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?  Did you think I'd be glowing?  Don't worry.  You can't catch it. Yuri kisses Dmitri on the cheek to reassure him.  Over his shoulder, Dmitri notices the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the SLK?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in 4.8. Dmitri is impressed. INT.  ODESSA MILITARY BASE - OFFICE.  DAY. YURI has a stack of VCR's, cartons of cigarettes, Johnnie Walker Black Label on the table in front of DMITRI who drinks from his hip flask throughout the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't just sell you government property, Yuri.  I have to report--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --Report to who?  Moscow?  As of last week Moscow is in a foreign country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: New flag, new boss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no new boss yet.  They're too busy squabbling over who gets the presidential holiday home at the Black Sea. Dmitri can't deny it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful.  The ones who know don't care any more.  The ones who care don't know. (nodding to a safe built into the floor) Show me your inventory. Dmitri hesitates, knocks back his vodka, then opens the safe - produces a document. INT.  ODESSA MILITARY BASE - ARMORY.  DAY. Crates of machine guns from floor to ceiling.  DMITRI gives YURI a tour of the armory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many Kalashnikovs do you have?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking to his unopened crates, more and more agitated)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) (barking an order to a CREWMAN, referring to the Panamanian flag)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) (to the PAINTER, already blacking out the name, KRISTOL)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) (agitated, grasping the line of the scaffold)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jamming his handgun in Vitaly's eye socket)
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: ILLUSTRATING THE ANATOMY OF AN ARMS DEAL

dialogue.raw_text: (holding her skirt in the wind to protect her modesty)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pretending to be impressed with the photos)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) (reassuring word as he whisks Ava into the car)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Irina, regarding a nativity scene on a Christmas card)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont' d) (at a loss for anything better)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (referring to the inventory in his hand)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Is that a "4"?  It doesn't look like a "4" to me.  It looks more like a "1".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's a "4".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's whatever we say it is because no one else knows the difference. Dmitri finally gets it.  Yuri examines a Kalashnikov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kalashnikovs for a battalion.  Your stocks are dangerously depleted, Dmitri. You should order more from the factory. This is too much for Dmitri.  He stops, confronts Yuri - takes back the AK-47 Yuri is inspecting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone will work this out, Yuri.  What happens then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll cut them in.  Anyway, what could happen - you're the luckiest man alive. EXT.  ODESSA MILITARY BASE.  DUSK. The sun sets over a grassy field.  YURI sits alone - closely inspects a Kalashnikov. It is a strange moment between a man and his favorite gun. As we hear Yuri's thoughts, we are treated to lovingly shot close ups of the weapon and its features often seen in slow motion:  Sun glistening off the chromed barrel.  Folding metal stock arcing elegantly into place.  Precise docking of the 30-round curved magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Avtomat Kalashnikova, model of 1947 - more commonly known as the AK-47 or Kalashnikov. It's the world's most popular assault ritle - a weapon all fighters love.  An elegantly simple nine pound amalgamation of forged steel and molded plastic.  It doesn't break, jam or over-heat.  It will shoot whether its covered in mud or filled with sand.  It's so easy, even a child can use it.  And they do. The Russians put the gun on a coin. Mozambique put it on their flag.  Since the end of the Cold War, the Kalashnikov has become the Russian peoples' greatest export - after that comes vodka and suicidal novelists.  One thing's for sure, no one was lining up to buy their cars. We reveal where Yuri is sitting - on the roof of a rusting Russian sedan, the Vaz 4-door.  A goat is eating the upholstery. Yuri checks on the crates of AK-47's being loaded into a convoy of trucks.  In the background, the armory, full a week ago, is now virtually empty.  Yuri smiles a satisfied smile. His reverie is interrupted by the sound of a car horn. A commotion at the gate.  Another large, black Mercedes is parked there, DRIVER leaning on the horn. YURI smiles as he sees the passenger emerge from the car - SIMEON ZAHAROFF.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course my idea was not entirely unique. I had rivals. Simeon angrily confronts the SOLDIER at the gate. DMITRI puts on his cap, about to investigate.  YURI stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a friend of mine. Dmitri shrugs and complies.  Yuri strides towards the gate. EXT.  ODESSA MILITARY BASE - GATE.  DUSK. SIMEON, flanked by two hefty BODYGUARDS, is in the face of a YOUNG OFFICER. The Officer is flanked by three SOLDIERS, Kalashnikovs resting on their hips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know who the fuck I am?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the fuck cares who the fuck you are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I demand to see your commanding officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't demand shit. Simeon reconsiders his position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just give me back my papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What papers? The Officer turns on his heel and returns to his guard station with the passport, starts watching TV.  The Bodyguards make to follow but the Soldiers close ranks, barring their path. Simeon fumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're late, Simeon. YURI breezes past the Soldiers with an easy familiarity.  He enters the guard station as if he owns it. From beside his car, Simeon watches as Yuri jovially discusses the situation with the Young Officer.  After a moment Yuri slips the Officer money in exchange for Simeon's passport. Yuri emerges from the station and returns the passport to the veteran gunrunner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I invited you for a drink once before. Perhaps now you will accept my invitation. INT.  ODESSA HOTEL BAR.  NIGHT. YURI and SIMEON sit at a table near the back of the bar.  Yuri flirts with the BARMAID delivering drinks and a shellfish appetizer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sell guns?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you'd like to come to my room and see my bazooka. The Barmaid giggles and exits. Simeon is clearly disquieted by the change in the balance of power or maybe it's the bad early-nineties pop music.  His BODYGUARDS sit at the table behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look a little lost, Simeon.  Is the world changing too fast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am here, aren't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not all of you, I think. Simeon's look begs explanation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've gotten so rich selling for the CIA, you can't get that ideology completely out of your head.  The empire was evil for too long. Simeon shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't deny, it takes some getting used to. Last week we were trying to beat their brains in and now we're going into business together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no place in gunrunning for politics anymore, Simeon.  I sell to leftists, rightists.  I'd sell to pacifists but they're not the most regular of customers. Yuri leans forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, you're not a true internationalist until you've supplied weapons to kill your own countrymen. Simeon regards the young man with a mixture of fear and admiration pours himself another drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand you have Ukraine in your pocket but there are the other satellite states. Bulgaria, Hungary, Poland, Belarus.  Instead of cutting each other's throats, it may be more profitable to work together.  What do you think? Yuri smiles - the proposal is the victory he has been seeking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you are the amateur now.  I think you suffer from a philosophical disadvantage - you have a philosophy.  I think you should go with your instincts - your first instinct. Simeon is confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am the same man who was not good enough for you before.  I am not good enough for you now. Simeon blanches.  Yuri gets up. Simeon holds his rival's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The problem with gunrunners going to war is there's no shortage of ammunition. Yuri departs. INT.  HOTEL ROOM - ODESSA HOTEL.  NIGHT. YURI and the BARMAID never make it to the bed.  Still clothed, they bang each other against the door of his hotel room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back then, it was all for sale... EXT.  UKRAINE MILITARY BASE.  DAY. Row after row of tanks, armored personnel carriers and helicopter gunships in mothballs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helicopters, torpedo boats, armored personnel carriers, whole tank divisions. DMITRI, flask in hand, and YURI are given a tour of the surplus hardware by one of Dmitri's brother officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --I'll tell you what I'll do.  Buy six, you get one free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about tech support?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No problem. Yuri and Dmitri come upon an oily-faced BOY, perched on the cockpit of a helicopter gunship - he wears an ill-fitting uniform, several sizes too big.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son, get off there before you get hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the tech support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's twelve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirteen.  Almost fourteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kids grow up fast around here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can take it apart in his sleep. Yuri shrugs, shakes the Major's hand. EXT.  HILL OVERLOOKING ODESSA HARBOR.  DAY. THE POV FROM A PAIR OF BINOCULARS - in the crosshairs, JACK VALENTINE, at a surprise checkpoint, staring through binoculars of his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you? YURI, on his belly to avoid detection, slithers back to the roadway - hands the binoculars to a YOUNG SOLDIER. DMITRI stands beside the convoy of trucks parked barely out of view of the checkpoint, including Yuri's Mercedes and a huge open-bed tractor-trailer carrying a Russian Hind helicopter gunship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we were supposed to be watching for these checkpoints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can I?  You keep selling my helicopters. You're too greedy, Yuri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to go back. Dmitri regards the trucks, each one longer than the road is wide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll be going in reverse.  We can't turn around for a mile. The YOUNG SOLDIER on lookout calls to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're coming. Yuri grabs the binoculars.  Sure enough, Valentine and his agents are climbing into their Interpol Jeeps and driving towards them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shoot it out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And start an international fucking incident - no, no, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I've got paperwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for the gunship.  Yuri, you know the penalty for sanction-busting - selling a military helicopter? Yuri gazes at the Russian Mi-24V helicopter gunship, bristling with armaments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not a military helicopter.  It's a rescue helicopter. Yuri turns to the Boy referred to as "tech support".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get to work, Son. The boy pulls a wrench from his pocket. SEVERAL MINUTES LATER The Interpol Jeeps crest the rise and pull in front of the convoy - VALENTINE and his agents exit, guns drawn. DMITRI and the UKRAINIAN SOLDIERS stiffen, their weapons also at the ready.  An uneasy stand-off. YURI gestures for calm.  He greets Valentine warmly - offers his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri Orlov. In reply, an Interpol Agent unceremoniously slams Yuri into the side of his truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papers. Again Yuri waves off Dmitri and his men, about to come to his aid. Yuri courteously hands over his passport and other documentation to the skeptical Valentine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Orlov, always in the wrong place at the right time.  We've met before.  Off the coast of Colombia. (feigning memory loss) What was the name of that freighter - I can't remember.  Was it the Kono or the Kristol?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crew called that vessel a lot of names - none of them repeatable in polite company. Valentine turns his attention to the helicopter - now devoid of its weapons.  An Interpol Agent escorts Yuri at gunpoint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new MP-5.  Do you need a silencer for that? Valentine ignores the banter, inspects Yuri's documentation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The end-user certificate for this aircraft states Burkina Faso.  Nice.  Did you type it yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for humanitarian missions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a humanitarian? Yuri shrugs - why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a killing machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not any more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to the nephew. It's true.  Yuri has had the armaments detached.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you get the memo?  The war's over. What can they do with military hardware but convert to civilian use?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only way you could die from this baby is if a food drop hits you. Valentine's face hardens at the flippant remark. Still at gunpoint, Yuri is escorted to the smaller second truck in the convoy.  Stacked inside the container are the helicopter's hurriedly removed missiles and the Boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Also going to Burkina Faso?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But to a different client at a different address. Valentine, incensed, throws Yuri up against the truck himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you take me for?  A complete fucking fool?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not complete, Sir.  And while I hesitate to tell you your job, I must point out that when shipped separately the weapons and the aircraft both comply with the current Interpol trade standards and practices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You expect me to believe this is a coincidence?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see how certain people might interpret it as suspicious but thank God we live in a world where suspicion alone does not constitute a crime. Valentine regards Yuri closely - this foe is more formidable than he imagined. Valentine looks to the gun in his hand, contemplating crossing the line.  He finally holsters his gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yuri Orlov.  You and I are going to be seeing a lot of each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can hardly wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch out for the time you don't see me. Yuri, Dmitri and the Boy watch Valentine speed away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What an asshole. Yuri looks to the boy, askance - a Yuri in the making. EXT.  ODESSA HARBOR.  DAY. YURI supervises the loading of the cargo onto a freighter.  Checking the empty trucks, he is just in time to see SIMEON and his HENCHMEN climb into their car, parked beside his own car, some distance away. As he drives off, Simeon and Yuri make brief eye-contact. Yuri looks for DMITRI, exiting a nearby restroom - carrying his hip flask as usual, the worse for drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was he doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trying to beat your offer.  I sent him on his way.  He doesn't understand the concept of loyalty. Dmitri glances at the SOLDIERS around the docks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speaking of loyalty, too many people know. I have to make pay-offs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry.  There're more VCR's.  I left them in your new car. Dmitri's face lights up.  Yuri hands him the keys to the SKL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even your enemy was admiring that car.  I am the luckiest man alive. Dmitri hands his hip flask to Yuri.  Yuri watches Dmitri walk to the car and climb in for a test drive. A look of realization on Yuri's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dmit--!!! The car erupts as if it has been punched by a fist beneath the earth. Recovered from the blast, Yuri runs up to the burning car but is beaten back by the flames.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT.  DOCKS.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON a bent Mercedes medallion, now worn around the BOY's neck. He regards it forlornly.
